skos:ConceptScheme.dcterms:title: {"id": "a0b22061-d795-4470-8e19-2dd507fab014", "value": "Historic England Maritime Object Material"}
skos:ConceptScheme.dcterms:description: {"id": "08772307-b660-4fed-b1f2-c27abf71c87b", "value": "Used for record the construction materials of maritime vessels and, where appropriate, their cargoes."}

skos:Concept.skos:scopeNote: {"id": "8a2d5996-d64e-4725-8965-bf7a72043115", "value": "A purple or violet variety of quartz often used in jewelry. Amethyst is a semi-precious stone which owes its violet colour to irridation, iron impurities, and the presence of trace elements, which result in complex crystal lattice substitutions."}

{"id": "5923cd37-ba11-468b-80b1-95a736844656", "value": "A coloured, glass-like substance (opaque or partially opaque) that is fused to the surface of metal or glass or pottery for decorative or protective purposes."}
{"id": "2248ebfe-599d-4b9d-a095-3f278058e3fe", "value": "A light, soft, moderately-strong wood obtained from trees of the genus Picea."}
{"id": "077298e6-3bdc-4de2-bb2c-5aa559d4fb5d", "value": "Materials used in the manufacture of objects."}
{"id": "e7c4722e-0969-4cf6-bc13-c8a532d516ac", "value": "A thin, flexible material made from the pulp of wood or other fibrous matter which is then pressed and dried to form sheets."}
{"id": "3f8ec054-674d-4398-8577-8221dc09b875", "value": "An early plastic formed from a condensation reaction of phenol with formaldehyde which was developed by Leo Baekeland in 1907."}
{"id": "0a743312-e3ba-4920-be3f-277aeaa2ce67", "value": "A hard material formed by firing clay. For pottery, use POTTERY."}
{"id": "119cd923-2497-4e94-9daf-bd3fd83831f5", "value": "Elastic polymeric substance made from the latex of a tropical plant or synthetically"}
{"id": "8ab0259e-8e9d-45f5-bd62-4a70bcd38650", "value": "The black, lightweight and porous residue of partly burnt wood."}
{"id": "d0a21616-f9e7-4c80-8e58-d98ab8a18c6f", "value": "A hard, compact, unprocessed, fibrous cellulose substance. The roots, trunks and branches of trees and shrubs consist of this tissue."}
{"id": "fa608299-b04d-4a9b-a71b-84c45d4dbc90", "value": "Natural inorganic substance possessing a definite chemical composition in a crystalline form. See MINERAL Class List for narrow terms."}
{"id": "40d6569b-3ba5-42e9-a87b-79f8b4ec73da", "value": "A material made from extremely fine fibres of glass and is used as a reinforcing agent for many polymer products."}
{"id": "624a2037-f69b-4d9c-8a71-c3355c6f4955", "value": "Pertaining to or deriving from a living organism. See ANIMAL Class list for narrow terms."}

{"id": "1295ad2a-a81e-4775-9a5f-f70e27bd51a0", "value": "Class of elements and alloys that are characteristically lustrous,ductile, fusible and malleable. These are extracted from ore minerals originally existing in nature and processed before becoming a recognisable metal. See METAL Class List for narrow terms"}
{"id": "c90b25de-6ec1-4d01-a6c9-6626aa9250f5", "value": "Any of the pieces of hard tissue consisting largely of calcium phosphate that make up the skeleton of a vertebrate animal."}

{"id": "8032c43c-dbb8-42f1-83c3-2841001dd92a", "value": "A form of bone, which grows on the heads of members of the deer family and is shed annually. Antler can be used by man for a variety of purposes"}

{"id": "cc7c9109-a86d-413c-9d4f-2a146fa85ef7", "value": "Originally obtained by burning limestone to produce quicklime. Now a fine grey powder made from a mixture of limestone and clay used with water and sand to make mortar or with water, sand and aggregate to make concrete."}

{"id": "2cb45671-5898-4990-82c1-47a97e605718", "value": "Collective term for a hard, fine grained, dark coloured metamorphic rock, which splits easily; hence its common use as a roofing and flooring material, and a functional description for any rectangular, sheet, roofing material."}

{"id": "3ffa7412-f98d-4284-b89c-030917fa4756", "value": "A silicate mineral used since the Bronze Age as gemstones and abrasives. Found in many colours including red, orange, yellow, green, purple, brown, blue, black, pink and colourless."}
{"id": "2a8480a0-7237-4c37-9cce-23b6b6ec0f38", "value": "Crystalline allotropic form of carbon used in pencils, as a lubricant etc."}
{"id": "c9165031-e7f9-4fdc-9d73-cbba4535f2e3", "value": "Soft, very fine grained, dark coloured, sedimentary rock which splits easily."}
{"id": "8d9d50c3-c8b8-434b-998c-1e0b96debdac", "value": "Coarse basaltic rock."}
{"id": "36660594-3977-464b-a75c-e19340adac44", "value": "A hard, coarse grained, durable igneous rock. Can be used decoratively or as a main material. Found throughout the country."}

{"id": "2ec5d0ea-4c36-44fa-9b3d-6c51996d4228", "value": "A brownish-red mineral commonly used as a semi-precious gemstone. A variety of the silica mineral chalcedony coloured by impurities of iron oxide."}
{"id": "0da94ef0-4639-4554-8f6a-5a748c4b7b16", "value": "Medium to coarse grained metamorphic rock, colour being determined by its dominant mineral. Often used for floor and wall cladding."}
{"id": "0705a3dd-be92-4562-a729-1820fcdc0464", "value": "Soft, white, porous sedimentary rock, a form of limestone composed of the mineral calcite."}

{"id": "605934fa-3184-4b2d-b37c-e3428a9dd552", "value": "Sedimentary rock consisting mainly of calcium carbonate. Varying in grain size, colour and hardness, quarried and used throughout the country."}
{"id": "e9d2025e-6a7e-45b2-8593-80283bf2b5f8", "value": "A hard, igneous rock formed from the cooling of molten volcanic magma."}
{"id": "1bb18097-81bd-4446-93a0-70d1d0416fbc", "value": "A sedimentary rock primarily composed of silt sized particles."}
{"id": "95126840-d9c9-4702-af79-84f058e92cf9", "value": "A sedimantary rock composed of fine grained clay particles. Flaky mudstone is called shale."}
{"id": "d7149613-e4c6-4807-9b8a-00bd277f9fc2", "value": "Rock of definite form and size, usually artificially shaped."}
{"id": "f5d12d6a-6427-4138-aa66-bb89ac4afbfa", "value": "An ornamental green stone of the mineral nephrite."}

{"id": "f779022b-e486-471d-8f6f-2a42d054182e", "value": "A hard, translucent variety of jade which is rarer than the other varieties of nephrite as a result considered to be the best and very desirable."}
{"id": "67aa8410-26dd-4f83-bb3e-f71ca7bf6eb6", "value": "Geologist's term for any dark coloured, slightly metamorphosed igneous rock. Index with specific stone type where given."}
{"id": "cca292d7-3bd8-46bd-9a07-9c8c0954a932", "value": "Conglomerate consisting of rounded flint pebbles held together in a natural silica and sand cement."}

{"id": "bc236dc9-4ebb-4826-85e7-1979f539bcc4", "value": "Collective name for, in a true geological sense, a metamorphosed limestone, eg. Carrara marble, and, in the British sense any decorative stone that will take a polish, eg. Purbeck marble. In the latter's case index with specific stone type where given"}

{"id": "b2d296bf-ae61-4c01-aee3-61142630a67c", "value": "A coarse grained metamorphic rock that is composed maily of green, brown or black amphibole minerals and plagioclase feldspar. Amphiboles are usually members of the hornblende group."}

{"id": "23b5a94c-ad1f-438d-9d33-a50552865f6d", "value": "Geologically sandstone consists of particles of quartz naturally cemented together by either silica, calcium or iron. It is this geological composition that accounts for the varying colours and grain sizes found in the many building sandstones."}
{"id": "95fa764e-ffbe-4253-a543-8fa93ca024d5", "value": "A straight-grained, durable and often resinous timber obtained from trees of the genus Pinus."}
{"id": "62894b29-44bd-4d87-855e-06b453b4180d", "value": "Medium grained, hard, white/grey coloured stone consisting of quartz and often silica, produced by the metamorphosis of sandstone."}

{"id": "18e9103f-3a6e-405d-9328-86c137f059e7", "value": "A clay-based ceramic fired at low kiln temperatures (c.800-1200 degrees). Essentially, earthenwares are porous and require glazing for most applications. This term has been used interchangeably with TERRACOTTA and with POTTERY"}

{"id": "71cb5faf-2c72-4525-b8ad-8202d23f2efb", "value": "Hard, transparent, often coloured mineral. Can be found on its own as crystals and veins but also as a major constituent of rocks such as granite. Often used decoratively."}

{"id": "bf8f3a04-9ace-4110-8a7c-b95648b23692", "value": "Onyx is a cryptocrystalline form of quartz. It is a semi-precious stone that is usually cut as a cabochon, or into beads, and is also used for intaglios and cameos."}
{"id": "41f87d61-16d2-439f-9f50-2df64db019bd", "value": "A precious metal of lustrous white colour with great malleability and ductility."}

{"id": "149a8980-c451-4587-9f5b-390ec242d095", "value": "Blue-white metal, obtained from ore, and used commercially for roofing, galvanizing iron, or in alloys. Also used in the 19th century as sheathing for ship's hulls."}

{"id": "a9bb5fd6-a67f-4925-a232-b28824cc45e6", "value": "A glass-like compound first made in ancient Egypt. It involves coating a core material of powdered quartz with a vitreous alkaline glaze. Also the name given to a tin-glazed earthenware."}
{"id": "f2307653-896a-4672-a793-a0091e727d61", "value": "Hard, protective covering made largely of calcium salts secreted by soft bodied invertebrate animals."}
{"id": "f0c8282c-6973-422d-9c64-53ff2eeef8a0", "value": "Animal skin that has been hardened or treated by a tanning process."}

{"id": "ae0f0543-e067-4eca-830f-b051b660b607", "value": "A hydrated aluminium phosphate mineral sometimes used as a semi-precious stone, and for carvings and ornamental use. Named after Variscia, the historical name of the Vogtland in Germany. Mainly green in colour."}
{"id": "d8fd8268-b529-4d42-a3f1-b355a1d79300", "value": "Hard, corrosive alloy of copper and tin."}
{"id": "7cf06fac-9aeb-4c11-9ff0-b6843c79ec4a", "value": "A form of volcanic glass with similar properties to FLINT and often used in the manufacture of sharp-edged tools."}

{"id": "b669ab97-f74d-41c9-8b62-02ef8b520597", "value": "A soft, lustrous low-melting crystalline metallic element that is malleable and ductile at ordinary temperatures and that is used as a protective coating, in tinfoil, and in soft solders and alloys."}
{"id": "112de7dc-a346-460a-8b9f-489c938b0213", "value": "A ceramic made from clay and fired in a kiln or oven. This term has been used interchangeably with EARTHENWARE and with TERRACOTTA"}
{"id": "041017ca-0201-4c66-8fe1-fc740d82fcdc", "value": "Hard, unglazed, brown, versatile earthenware which can be used as a tile or moulded into statuary."}
{"id": "b40a0a09-c041-4aed-90ba-006a4362f8ed", "value": "A precious metal characterized by its yellow colour and resistance to tarnishing."}
{"id": "c34ca725-1225-46e1-9a8f-8853a4642540", "value": "A green coloured gemstone. A variety of the mineral beryl coloured green by trace amounts of chromium and sometimes vanadium."}
{"id": "0c64fc13-21eb-4856-a78c-60554897a3e5", "value": "A deciduous conifer native to Britain and Europe supplying durable and waterproof timber suitable for shipbuilding features such as masts."}
{"id": "4da05a5b-d825-4a7a-b7ab-f216fb9b3951", "value": "A hard, bone-like material obtained from animal teeth."}
{"id": "6eafb49c-40ef-4857-ab34-cd9f00311f2e", "value": "A hard, white, fine-grained substance forming the main part of the tusks of elephants, walruses, hippos and narwhals."}
{"id": "9d701326-cfaa-4370-bcbc-11637997f235", "value": "A strong, durable alloy of iron and carbon."}
{"id": "14cc8b32-a9ed-444d-a74b-6f27f1dbaa20", "value": "A native hardwood of the Beech family with hard and durable characteristics which traditionally made it appropriate for structural work."}
{"id": "33c0fea0-fc13-4afc-b31a-db8f1a186508", "value": "Transparent, hard substance made by fusing soda-silica which solidifies from a molten state."}

{"id": "c8e965b2-46b4-4159-9f1d-6822d55fa68d", "value": "Hard, durable, dark grey stone, the purest native form of silica, which can either be used decoratively or as a main material. Predominantly found in East Anglia and the South East."}
{"id": "71eea0fd-b426-4a6b-8d76-953521423fae", "value": "A malleable, ductile ferromagnetic metal widely used for structural and decorative purposes."}

{"id": "2d65af40-2eb3-4e61-b906-ad366802938c", "value": "Dark and dense hardwood timber which may be sourced from various species of true ebony from southern Asia and Africa, but the name may also be given to dark hardwoods from elsewhere, e.g. the Americas."}

{"id": "2221135e-ec4a-4a55-a4df-892451d9c943", "value": "North American wood, the name being applied either to the American Larch; or to the Black or Ridge-pole Pine of inland areas; and the Scrub Pine of maritime regions."}
{"id": "13e6a500-5016-4598-b1f8-0550ddeda9cf", "value": "A hard, black form of lignite that takes a brilliant polish. It is used in jewellery and for ornamentation."}
{"id": "bf191faa-64da-4cd7-b2e3-eb9505b5352e", "value": "The timber from genus Betula, found in Europe and North America, particularly in northern regions."}

{"id": "38a1ff0b-7847-4434-ad81-c32bf84e7100", "value": "Use for objects made from coal or for stray finds of coal where the association with a wreck site is not proven and thus cannot be stated as either cargo or bunkers."}
{"id": "27cf3ea8-9195-4356-8988-672e1c7b9b65", "value": "A white ductile metal used, for example, in alloys, for instruments, and in aircraft construction."}
{"id": "2d92ada1-7312-470d-b6a7-1ac0d1e2a5b8", "value": "An alloy which is composed predominantly of tin (c.85-99 percent)."}

{"id": "d1efbf7a-7c84-4435-adcf-307fd7b5d12f", "value": "A metallic element often used in alloys and historically used in pottery and glass-making, paints, enamelling, and in cosmetics and medicine. Often derived from its sulphite ore, stibnite."}
{"id": "2ef6399d-30f3-4177-86fa-b1e10266d732", "value": "A metallic substance made by combining two or more elements at least one of which is a metal. Use more specific terms where known."}
{"id": "3d2bdfa0-9f13-4a8d-9330-82384f00223d", "value": "An alloy where the predominant component metal is copper."}
{"id": "750d3f63-d0ad-4097-b0cc-b32af5042044", "value": "Metal alloy with lead as the principal component."}
{"id": "c18e0261-d3eb-412f-b7fd-5c10d6ba896a", "value": "Easily formed metal alloy composed of copper and zinc."}
{"id": "582554ea-efda-416d-a8e8-74c98b49ad51", "value": "A hard, durable wood obtained from trees of the genus Ulmus."}

{"id": "c2604591-3bce-4242-a88e-bc0e86c09b60", "value": "A conglomerate rock comprising well rounded flint pebbles in a very hard matrix of fine pale coloured sand, bound together by hard natural silica cement. The pebbles are usually coloured ochre or red and have black rims."}
{"id": "03296ef5-1b3c-4b6c-bbde-c76e7288c965", "value": "Metal used primarily for roofing and ornamental purposes, being lighter and stronger than lead."}
{"id": "edbe2b15-a5b2-4df2-9700-8601d40293cf", "value": "The wood of the evergreen coniferous tree characterized by single needle-like leaves and errect cones."}
{"id": "638656ed-3d98-4fd2-8428-668f7a2838a8", "value": "A hard silica rich rock, black or brown coloured, commonly found in nodular form."}

{"id": "60b28afd-b770-4d09-b8e8-b1ab25981e8b", "value": "Metal used primarily for roof coverings and window fittings. It is easy to work, can be worked cold and does not rust which makes it suitable for holding or repelling water."}
{"id": "579bcb5f-f47c-4edf-a4bd-90b8023f9495", "value": "A strong durable wood originating in India and south-east Asia."}

{"id": "5d2dc196-d50a-4b13-b2ee-d9aa60dbf54c", "value": "Alabaster is a name applied to varieties of two distinct minerals: gypsum and calcite. The finer kinds of alabaster are employed as an ornamental stone, especially for internal decoration as it's softness allows it to be carved into elaborate forms."}
{"id": "2fbe3d5b-c861-4a6d-9b14-ac866d3055c0", "value": "Horn is a hollow, bone-like projection consisting mainly of keratin, found on certain animals (sheep, cows, goats etc.)"}

{"id": "7db6a9c3-e1ad-43f5-916c-6b6b80912a83", "value": "Composed of sand, stones or other aggregate and cement mixed with water which sets in a hard mass. The material is usually associated with modern building but was developed by Romans where cement was obtained from quicklime."}
{"id": "68956aed-906d-48f9-92bb-0d120652b3bc", "value": "A semi-precious, fossilised resin usually used for ornamentation and jewellery."}
{"id": "ca2c764a-4b63-4655-b33b-321d42b459c9", "value": "A commonly coppiced wood from the genus Corylus."}

{"id": "b546fef8-ddc6-4bb0-a1ab-4224d2361762", "value": "A building material used for coating walls and ceilings. Plaster can refer to gypsum plaster (also known as plaster of Paris), lime plaster, or cement plaster."}
{"id": "dc3871e8-11f3-4938-9b05-cc31e8ba66b1", "value": "A fine grained earth which becomes more plastic when water is added and can be moulded and dried to make bricks, tile, pottery, etc."}
